articles.headline: Verizon Seals Long-Sought $130 Billion Deal to Own Wireless Unit
articles.snippet: Verizon will pay about $58.9 billion in cash and about $60.2 billion in stock for Vodafone’s stake. Other considerations are also part of the deal.
articles.abstract: Verizon will pay about $58.9 billion in cash and about $60.2 billion in stock for Vodafone’s stake. Other considerations are also part of the deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:15 p.m. | Verizon Communications agreed on Monday to spend $130 billion to take full control of its enormous wireless unit because it said it believed that the American desire for cellphones and broadband services was not yet nearly sated.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Mark Scott

articles.headline: Recession Reverses California Airport’s Growth
articles.snippet: Analysts say a change in how airlines operate has also affected business at Ontario International Airport.
articles.abstract: Analysts say a change in how airlines operate has also affected business at Ontario International Airport.
articles.lead_paragraph: ONTARIO, Calif. — Rolling into Ontario International Airport is a traveler’s delight. The parking lots, across from either terminal, are mostly vacant. The spacious, tidy terminals are filled with natural light and few lines at the ticket counters. Jostling around the baggage carousel is not like trying to box out LeBron James for a rebound — there is plenty of elbow room for everyone.

articles.headline: President Gains McCain’s Backing on Syria Attack
articles.snippet: The White House pushed forward for Congressional approval of an attack on Syria as President Obama got qualified support from a hawkish Republican critic, Senator John McCain.
articles.abstract: The White House pushed forward for Congressional approval of an attack on Syria as President Obama got qualified support from a hawkish Republican critic, Senator John McCain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House’s aggressive push for Congressional approval of an attack on Syria appeared to have won the tentative support of one of President Obama’s most hawkish critics, Senator John McCain, who said Monday that he would back a limited strike if the president did more to arm the Syrian rebels and the attack was punishing enough to weaken the Syrian military.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes, Michael R. Gordon and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: CBS Returns, Triumphant, to Cable Box
articles.snippet: An agreement with Time Warner Cable restores CBS and its related channels, like Showtime, to millions of cable subscribers largely in three major cities, New York, Los Angeles and Dallas.
articles.abstract: An agreement with Time Warner Cable restores CBS and its related channels, like Showtime, to millions of cable subscribers largely in three major cities, New York, Los Angeles and Dallas.
articles.lead_paragraph: CBS and Time Warner Cable ended their protracted contract dispute Monday evening with CBS winning not only a significant financial increase for its programming, but also its stake in the digital future.

articles.headline: A Bet on the Environment
articles.snippet: The company Mosaic functions as an online renewable energy bank, soliciting investments for solar projects and making loans for them.
articles.abstract: The company Mosaic functions as an online renewable energy bank, soliciting investments for solar projects and making loans for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just after his sophomore year at Yale in 2002, Billy Parish stood before a rapidly retreating glacier in India that feeds the Ganges River, convinced that he had come face to face with climate change and that he had to do something about it.

articles.headline: As Summers’s Odds Rise, Stimulus Easing Is Seen
articles.snippet: Anticipation that Lawrence H. Summers will be President Obama’s choice to lead the Federal Reserve Board has some investors speculating about a faster withdrawal of stimulus.
articles.abstract: Anticipation that Lawrence H. Summers will be President Obama’s choice to lead the Federal Reserve Board has some investors speculating about a faster withdrawal of stimulus.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The spreading expectation that President Obama will name Lawrence H. Summers to lead the Federal Reserve Board appears to be working against the central bank’s efforts to stimulate the economy.

articles.headline: McKinsey & Co. Isn’t All Roses in a New Book
articles.snippet: “The Firm,” by Duff McDonald, chronicles the rise of the world’s most influential management consulting firm, but also cites its many failures.
articles.abstract: “The Firm,” by Duff McDonald, chronicles the rise of the world’s most influential management consulting firm, but also cites its many failures.
articles.lead_paragraph: “You can’t get fired for hiring McKinsey & Company.”

articles.headline: Drawing a Line on Syria, U.S. Keeps Eye on Iran Policy
articles.snippet: Two recent diplomatic ventures have raised hopes that the United States will be able to strike Syria without compromising efforts toward easing tensions with Iran.
articles.abstract: Two recent diplomatic ventures have raised hopes that the United States will be able to strike Syria without compromising efforts toward easing tensions with Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Obama administration makes a case for punitive airstrikes on the Syrian government, its strongest card in the view of some supporters of a military response may be the need to send a message to another country: Iran. If the United States does not enforce its self-imposed “red line” on Syria’s use of chemical weapons, this thinking goes, Iran will smell weakness and press ahead more boldly in its quest for nuclear weapons.

articles.headline: U.S.-Russian Ties Still Fall Short of ‘Reset’ Goal
articles.snippet: Much fanfare surrounded American efforts to “reset” relations with Russia, but the two countries are now very far apart on issues like intervention in Syria.
articles.abstract: Much fanfare surrounded American efforts to “reset” relations with Russia, but the two countries are now very far apart on issues like intervention in Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just days before Vladimir V. Putin reassumed the presidency of Russia last year, President Obama dispatched his national security adviser to Moscow. Mr. Obama had made considerable progress with Dmitri A. Medvedev, the caretaker president, and wanted to preserve the momentum.

articles.headline: Microsoft Gets Nokia Units, and Leader
articles.snippet: Microsoft will acquire the handset and services business of Nokia for more than $7.1 billion in an all-cash deal, and Stephen Elop, the chief of Nokia and a former Microsoft executive, will rejoin Microsoft.
articles.abstract: Microsoft will acquire the handset and services business of Nokia for more than $7.1 billion in an all-cash deal, and Stephen Elop, the chief of Nokia and a former Microsoft executive, will rejoin Microsoft.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft said it has reached an agreement to acquire the handset and services business of Nokia for about $7.2 billion, in an audacious effort to transform Microsoft’s business for a mobile era that has largely passed it by.

articles.headline: House Leaders Express Their Support for Syria Strike
articles.snippet: President Obama won the support of Republican and Democratic leaders in the House for an attack on Syria, as a Senate panel agreed on the wording for a measure to permit military action.
articles.abstract: President Obama won the support of Republican and Democratic leaders in the House for an attack on Syria, as a Senate panel agreed on the wording for a measure to permit military action.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama won the support on Tuesday of Republican and Democratic leaders in the House for an attack on Syria, giving him a foundation to win broader approval for military action from a Congress that still harbors deep reservations.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Michael R. Gordon and Thom Shanker
